coredata.dc:title: Local structure of electron correlations in atomic systems
coredata.dc:creator: Pang, Tao
Campbell, C.E.
Krotscheck, E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The Jastrow—Feenberg functional variation method is applied to study electron correlations in atomic systems. The density and pair distributions of electrons are calculated by solving Euler—Lagrange equations for the pair distribution functions. From the calculated pair distributions, we examine the local structure of the exchange—correlation holes and find a sensitive dependence on the location of the electrons. Our theory gives correlation energies in good agreement with experimental data. We compare our results wit those from density functional theories.

Atomic systems are a useful laboratory for ex- amining electron correlations in highly inhomoge- neous, localized systems where one might expect strong correlation effects. Such correlation effects in small atomic systems and small molecules have been studied recently by Monte Carlo simulations [1]. In this Letter, we apply Jastrow Feenberg functional variation method to study correlation effects in at- oms and ions with four and ten electrons. The elec- tron correlation energies are evaluated and the re- suits are in good agreement with the experimental data. One of the design goals of the Jastrow Feenberg variational theory has been to deal with short-ranged correlations specifically [2,31; the recent extension of the method to inhomogeneous electronic systems such as metal surfaces [4] has made possible the study of atomic problems. The studies of ref. [4] have revealed an unexpected importance of the non- local structure of the short-ranged correlations be- tween pairs of electrons. Atomic systems are good candidates where similar effects can be important. Our results on the pair distribution functions in atomic systems provide the detailed structure of the Present address: Department of Physics, University of Cali- fornia, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA. 2 Present and permanent address. exchange correlation holes in the localized states; they provide a new point of view for comparison with, for example, density functional theories (DFT) [5]. Jastrow wave functions are normally used as im- portance functions for Monte Carlo simulations of atoms and molecules. It has been pointed out in ref [1] that a good choice of the importance function is essential to obtain a reasonably fast convergence of the simulations, but so far only simple parametrized forms have been used. The Jastrow functions used in our work are, within the restricted Hilbert space of variational wave functions, the best possible ones, and should therefore be excellent importance functions. A sec- ond approximation implicit to the Jastrow Feen- berg wave function is a collective approximation for the particle hole propagator [2,31. This approx- imation has been found to be very good for the ho- mogeneous electron gas, but it has to our knowledge not been tested for small systems. The electron densities for different atoms and ions are very close to ones obtained in HF approximation [6]. This is expected since the correlation correc- tions to the Hartree and Fock potentials are several orders of magnitude smaller than the Coulomb term. The basic new feature of our theory as compared with DFT is the central role played by the pair dis- tribution function. We show in figs. la le the cal- culated pair distribution for neon for the case that one of the electrons is located at the nucleus, and at a distance of 1 and 2 au from the nucleus. The pair distribution function for the electron in the center of the atom is typical of a high-density system (note that g(r, r)~1). As the reference electron is moved further away from the nucleus into the lower density regime, the short-ranged correlations become more important. g(r, r) decreases with decreasing density and be- comes nearly zero at very low density. The same ef- fect is observed in the homogeneous electron fluids [3,12]. We find that g(r, r ) is strongly anisotropic and depends on the location of the reference electron. The size of the correlation hole increases considerably at low electron density [6]. Moreover, in the regime of rapidly varying electron density, the exchange cor- relation hole is strongly anisotropie: in the direction of the nucleus, the correlations are similar to those in a high-density-electron gas, whereas they are sim- ilar to a low-density electron gas in the outward direction. The exchange correlation hole at a given density is, according to the present study, in general not well represented by the shape of the exchange correla- tion hole of the homogeneous electron fluids at the same density. The qualitative features found in our work are quite plausible, but quantitative estimates of the effect other than the solution of the many-body Schrodinger equation are hard to imagine. This latter negative quantity exceeds the positive Hartree Fock shift, giving a to- tal negative value for the correlation energy. Let us now discuss some of our numerical results. In table 1, we present numerical results of our theory for the correlation energies of ions and atoms with four and ten electrons. Our results give generally somewhat less binding than predicted by experi- ments, though the accuracy of our calculation is con- sistent with the quality of the FHNC//0 approxi- mation for the homogeneous electron gas [4]. We compare them in the table with experimental data [7] that have been corrected for relativistic and fi- nite nuclear mass effects, and with results from local spin-density (LSD) functional theory [8,9]. The generalized gradient approximation results of Langreth and Mehl (LM) [10] and Perdew [11] are also listed for comparison. The generalized gradient approximation needs to fit a parameter to the ex- perimental data, for example, the result for the neon atom [11]. The present theory is parameter free and can be applied to any atoms and ions without major modifications. The only case where our theoretical results are un- satisfactory is the Ne6~ ion. All computations have been performed on the Cray-2 at the Supercomputer Institute of the Uni- versity of Minnesota. A good numerical accuracy could generally be reached, depending on the size of the atom, within 2 20 min of Cray-2 time. We be- lieve that more than an order of magnitude of speed can still be gained by using a non-uniform mesh in the radial direction, which is adjusted to the local electron density variation. Therefore, we consider our approach quite promising for the study of larger at- oms and excited states. We also foresee applications in some condensed matter systems where the inhom- ogeneity is important, such as a d- or an f-impurity in jellium.
